case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh & Ors. v. Munwar Shoe Company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 373 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 373 of 1961. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 14, 1959 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 274 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1959, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 274 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 24, 1962 by K.DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. August 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K.DAS, J.-This is an appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appellants are State of Madhya Pradesh, Commissioner of Sales Tax MP, Sales Tax Officer Circle No.2 Indore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us are the State of the Madhya Pradesh, the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Pradesh. and the Sales Tax Officer, Circle No.2, Indore.

facts.text: Respondent carried on business of importing and selling footwear as Munwar Shoe Company, Indore.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent carried on the business of importing and selling different types of footwear in the State of Madhya Pradesh under the name and style of Munwar Shoe Company, Indore.

facts.text: Assessment year 1956-57, taxable turnover over Rs. 60,000.

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment year 1956-57 the taxable turnover of the goods sold by the respondent was determined to be a little over Rs. 60,000/-,

facts.text: Sales tax assessed under notification dated October 24, 1953 under s.5 of Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950, item 32 Sch.3.

anchor.surface_text: and he was assessed to sales tax on his taxable turnover in accordance with item 32 Sch.3 of the numberification dated October 24, 1953 issued under s. 5 of the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950

facts.text: Item 32: All leather goods and all shoes, chappals, footwear etc. taxable at sale by importer or manufacturer.

anchor.surface_text: Item 32 of Sch. 3 of the numberification referred to above was in these terms. No. Name of goods Point of sale in Madhya Bharat at which tax it payable 32 All leather goods Sale by importer and all shoes,

facts.text: Exemption notification dated May 27, 1955 under s.4(3) exempting certain shoes <= Rs. 1 per pair sold by manufacturer himself or family, hand-made no power.

anchor.surface_text: The first numberification was dated May 27, 1955 and was in these terms In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 4 3  of Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, Samvat 2007 the Rajpramukh has passed order exempting from the payment of sales tax,

facts.text: Superseded by notification dated January 28, 1956 exempting hand-made shoes etc. <= Rs.12/8/- sold by manufacturer or family member.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification was later superseded by another numberification dated January 28, 1956, which read as follows In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 4, sub-section 3  of the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, Samvat 2007 the Rajpramukh in supersession of the numberification No. 59 c  t  R. 412-54, dated 27-5-1955

facts.text: Respondent contended before STO that hand-made shoes <= Rs.12/8/- exempt under 1956 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytended before the Sale Tax Officer that he was number liable to pay any sales tax on the sale of hand-made shoes, chappal and other type of footwear whose sale price did number exceed Rs. 12/8/- per pair

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer order dated March 25, 1958 rejected exemption as respondent is importer not manufacturer.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer negatived this companytention. He pointed out in his order dated March 25, 1958 that the companydition laid down in the numberification to the effect that the sale must be by the manufacturer or any member of his family was number fulfilled,

facts.text: STO assessed sales tax on total turnover of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the Sales Tax Officer passed an order assessing sales tax on the total turnover of the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 in MP High Court, Misc. Petition No. 274 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the High Court of Madhya Pradesh by means of a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and in that petition the respondent said that the numberification dated January 28, 1956,

facts.text: In writ petition, respondent claimed exemption for hand-made imported footwear <= Rs.12/8/- or notification discriminatory under Art.304(a).

anchor.surface_text: the respondent said that the numberification dated January 28, 1956, exempted from tax all sales of footwear which fulfilled the following to companyditions, viz.,  a  such footwear was hand-made and number manufactured on power machine, and  b  the sale price whereof did number exceed Rs. 12/8/- per pair.

facts.text: High Court quashed assessment order dated March 25, 1958 on December 14, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: by which the said High Court quashed an assessment of sales tax made against the respondent for the assessment year 1956-57.

facts.text: High Court held exemption applies to hand-made shoes sold by importer if conditions met, reading in consonance with Art.301.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the petition of the respondent and held that the respondents companytention that hand-made shoes, chappals and footwear purchased by him directly from the manufacturer outside the State and imported by him for sale were entitled to exemption under the numberification dated January 28, 1956, must prevail.

facts.text: Supreme Court held interpretation of High Court incorrect; exemption requires sale by manufacturer or family in the State.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it has been companytended before us that the interpretation which the High Court put on the numberification dated January 28, 1956, is number companyrect. We think that this companytention is right and must be accepted.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.

facts.text: Respondent is importer and dealer, not manufacturer or family member.

anchor.surface_text: and as the respondent was an importer and dealer of footwear and number the manufacturer or a member of the family of the manufacturer, he was number entitled to claim any exemption under the numberification.

facts.text: Notification 1956 does not discriminate under Art.304(a) as conditions apply equally to local and imported footwear.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the numberification dated January 28, 1956 makes any such discrimination between footwear remanaufactured or produced in the State of Madhya Pradesh and footwear imported from other States as is prohibited by Art. 304 a  of of the Constitution.

facts.text: Exemption for protection of small hand-made manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that the exemption is for the protection and benefit of small manufacturers who make hand- made shoes of small value and who may be unable to companypete with large-scale manufacturers of footwear made on machines.

facts.text: If exemption notification invalid, original assessment under 1953 notification stands valid.

holdings.text: The interpretation which the High Court put on the notification dated January 28, 1956, is not correct; the notification lays down three conditions for exemption including sale by the manufacturer or any member of his family.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it has been contended before us that the interpretation which the High Court put on the notification dated January 28, 1956, is not correct. We think that this contention is right and must be accepted. The notification clearly lays down three conditions for the grant of exemption one of the conditions is that the sale must be of such shoes, chappals, country shoes and footwear as are hand-made and not manufactured on power machine the second condition

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of notification requires all three cumulative conditions; High Court deleted seller condition; refers to taxable sale in State under single point taxation per 1953 notification.

holdings.text: All the three conditions laid down in the notification must be fulfilled before the exemption referred to therein can be claimed and we cannot, by interpretation, delete one of the conditions.

anchor.surface_text: If the interpretation put by the High Court is correct, then the practical effect will be to obliterate one of the conditions laid down in the notification, namely, that the sale, which is the taxable event, must be by the manufacturer or any member of his family. We do not think that the notification is capable of such an interpretation. All the three conditions laid down in the notification must be fulfilled before the exemption referred to therein can be claimed and we cannot, by interpretation, delete one of the conditions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict construction prevents deletion of conditions; exemption tied to taxable event (sale by importer/manufacturer in State).

holdings.text: The notification dated January 28, 1956 does not contravene Art. 304(a) of the Constitution as it makes no discrimination between footwear manufactured in the State and imported from other States.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the notification contravenes Art. 304(a) of the Constitution... We do not think that the notification dated January 28, 1956 makes any such discrimination between footwear manufactured or produced in the State of Madhya Pradesh and footwear imported from other States as is prohibited by Art. 304(a) of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three conditions apply equally to local and imported footwear; no prohibited discrimination.

holdings.text: The exemption is for the protection and benefit of small manufacturers who make hand-made shoes of small value; such classification is reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that the exemption is for the protection and benefit of small manufacturers who make hand-made shoes of small value and who may be unable to compete with large-scale manufacturers of footwear made on machines. Such a classification in the interests of small manufacturers has often been made and upheld by this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification upheld citing precedents (Orient Weaving Mills, British India Corporation); reasonable under equality principles.

holdings.text: There is no discrimination under Art. 304(a) requiring out-of-state manufacturers to travel; conditions apply equally and Art. 304(a) concerns sales in the State.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree. The argument of learned counsel for the respondent is really an argument of inconvenience. The exemption by itself creates no discrimination between footwear manufactured or produced in the State and imported from outside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inconvenience not discrimination; all must sell in State for exemption; out-of-state sales not taxable anyway.

holdings.text: If the notification dated January 28, 1956 is invalid, the notification dated October 24, 1953 remains valid and the assessment on total turnover stands.

anchor.surface_text: if the notification in question is bad on the ground that it contravenes the provisions of Art. 304(a) of the Constitution, then the result will be that the notification dated January 28, 1956, will be void. This will not, however, affect the validity of the notification of October 24, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notifications independent: 1956 under s.4(3) exemption, 1953 under s.5 levy; invalid exemption revives levy on importer.

holdings.text: The principle in M/s Ram Narain Sons Ltd. does not apply as there is no wrongful inclusion if exemption invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The principle laid down by this Court in M/s Ram Narain Sons Ltd. v. Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax... will not apply in the present case for the simple reason that there is no wrongful inclusion of any item in the assessment order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Total turnover correctly assessed under 1953 notification if exemption fails; no exempted items wrongly included.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of High Court dated December 14, 1959 set aside; writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated December 14, 1959 and dismiss the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it has been contended before us that the interpretation which the High Court put on the notification dated January 28, 1956, is not correct. We think that this contention is right and must be accepted. The notification clearly lays down three conditions for the grant of exemption one of the conditions is that the sale must be of such shoes, chappals, country shoes and footwear as are hand-made and not manufactured on power machine the second condition
For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.
rer. Learned companynsel has submitted that the respondent is an importer who sells footwear in the State, and he will be liable to tax on all footwea

edges.explanation: Holding prohibiting deletion of conditions by interpretation supports application of strict interpretation

anchor.surface_text: rer. Learned companynsel has submitted that the respondent is an importer who sells footwear in the State, and he will be liable to tax on all footwea

edges.explanation: h2 requires all three conditions fulfilled and cannot delete one, addressing i1 on exemption regardless of seller

anchor.surface_text: If the interpretation put by the High Court is correct, then the practical effect will be to obliterate one of the conditions laid down in the notification, namely, that the sale, which is the taxable event, must be by the manufacturer or any member of his family. We do not think that the notification is capable of such an interpretation. All the three conditions laid down in the notification must be fulfilled before the exemption referred to therein can be claimed and we cannot, by interpretation, delete one of the conditions.
For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.

On the question whether the notification contravenes Art. 304(a) of the Constitution... We do not think that the notification dated January 28, 1956 makes any such discrimination between footwear manufactured or produced in the State of Madhya Pradesh and footwear imported from other States as is prohibited by Art. 304(a) of the Constitution.
For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.

It is obvious that the exemption is for the protection and benefit of small manufacturers who make hand-made shoes of small value and who may be unable to compete with large-scale manufacturers of footwear made on machines. Such a classification in the interests of small manufacturers has often been made and upheld by this Court.
For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.

edges.explanation: The holding that there is no discrimination under Art. 304(a) directly addresses the issue of discriminatory treatment of out-of-state manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree. The argument of learned counsel for the respondent is really an argument of inconvenience. The exemption by itself creates no discrimination between footwear manufactured or produced in the State and imported from outside.
For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.

This will not, however, affect the validity of the notification of October 24, 1953.
For the reasons given above, we would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and- order of the High Court dated December 14, 1949 and dismiss the writ petition.
